hedline.hl1: Two Sleek Hotels For New Orleans

abstract.p: Sheraton Four Points Hotel, and renamed W New Orleans, and Hotel de la Poste, both in New Orleans' French Quarter, are renovated and reopened; photo (M)

block.p: Two renovations have brought a bold postmodern twist to New Orleans's upscale hotel scene, where furnishings tend to be antique, real or fake, fabrics are often flowery, and charm has long been mandatory.

The more visible of the hotels is the W New Orleans in the Central Business District, formerly a Sheraton Four Points and a neighbor of Harrah's new casino. Nearby, the W New Orleans-French Quarter is a dramatic remake of the Hotel de la Poste.

Two renovations have brought a bold postmodern twist to New Orleans's upscale hotel scene, where furnishings tend to be antique, real or fake, fabrics are often flowery, and charm has long been mandatory.

The more visible of the hotels is the W New Orleans in the Central Business District, formerly a Sheraton Four Points and a neighbor of Harrah's new casino. Nearby, the W New Orleans-French Quarter is a dramatic remake of the Hotel de la Poste.

But neither of the hotels, both of which opened officially on May 11, is without a trace of Louisiana culture. Beyond the striking red and gold velvets, black leather and oversize chrome tick-tack-toe games in the small reception area of the W in the French Quarter, there are voodoo dolls for sale in the guest rooms' snack bars, for $7 each. The same is true of the W in the Central Business District, where there is a marble-and-glass staircase and a backgammon set made of cloth, and chaises longues sit legless in the playfully decorated lobby.

As in other W properties, both the 98-unit French Quarter hotel and its sibling, which has 400 guest rooms and 23 suites, are furnished with beds outfitted with pillow-topped mattresses and down comforters. The rooms' 27-inch television sets are equipped with wireless keyboards offering fast Internet access.
At the downtown W, the signature restaurant is Zoe Bistrot, where the cuisine is French. In a room off the lobby, Whiskey Blue is a relative of cocktail lounges in Manhattan and elsewhere.
At the French Quarter W, an Italian-style restaurant, Bacco, run by the Brennan family, who run Commander's Palace, is a holdover from the Hotel de la Poste.
Rates at the W New Orleans-French Quarter, 316 Chartres Street, (504) 581-1200, fax (504) 522-3208, start at $139; in high season (roughly fall, winter and early spring), $199 to $339.
At the W New Orleans, 333 Poydras Street, (504) 525-9444, fax (504) 581-7179, rates start at $129; in high season, $179 to $339. Both hotels have pools; the W New Orleans has a fitness center.
